messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 61 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Local Test for Unitarily Invariant Properties of Bipartite Quantum States

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the power of local test for bipartite quantum states. Our central result is that, for properties of bipartite pure states, unitary invariance on one part implies an optimal (over all global testers) local tester acting only on the other part. This suggests a canonical local tester for entanglement spectra (i.e., Schmidt coefficients), and reveals that purified samples offer no advantage in property testing of mixed states. As applications, we show new sample lower bounds, for example: • The first general lower bound Ω​(r/ε2)Ω𝑟superscript𝜀2\Omega(r/\varepsilon^{2}) for testing whether the Schmidt rank of a bipartite state is at most r𝑟r or ε𝜀\varepsilon-far, settling an open question raised in the survey of Montanaro and de Wolf (ToC 2016). • A lower bound Ω​((n+r)⋅r/ε2)Ω⋅𝑛𝑟𝑟superscript𝜀2\Omega((\sqrt{n}+\sqrt{r})\cdot\sqrt{r}/\varepsilon^{2}) for testing whether an n𝑛n-partite state is a matrix product state of bond dimension r𝑟r or ε𝜀\varepsilon-far, improving the prior lower bound Ω​(n/ε2)Ω𝑛superscript𝜀2\Omega(\sqrt{n}/\varepsilon^{2}) by Soleimanifar and Wright (SODA 2022) and Ω​(r)Ω𝑟\Omega(\sqrt{r}) by Aaronson et al. (ITCS 2024). Furthermore, when perfect completeness is required, we provide a matching lower bound Ω​(r2/ε2)Ωsuperscript𝑟2superscript𝜀2\Omega(r^{2}/\varepsilon^{2}) with respect to r𝑟r and ε𝜀\varepsilon. • A matching lower bound Ω​(d/ε2)Ω𝑑superscript𝜀2\Omega(d/\varepsilon^{2}) for testing whether a d𝑑d-dimensional bipartite state is maximally entangled or ε𝜀\varepsilon-far, showing that the algorithm of O’Donnell and Wright (STOC 2015) is optimal for this task. Beyond sample complexity, we also contribute new quantum query lower bounds: • A query lower bound Ω~​(d/Δ)~Ω𝑑Δ\widetilde{\Omega}(\sqrt{d/\Delta}) for the d𝑑d-dimensional entanglement entropy problem with gap ΔΔ\Delta,444Ω~​(⋅)~Ω⋅\widetilde{\Omega}\lparen\cdot\rparen suppreses polylogarithmic factors. improving the prior best Ω​(d4)Ω4𝑑\Omega\lparen\sqrt[4]{d}\rparen by She and Yuen (ITCS 2023) and Ω~​(1/Δ)~Ω1Δ\widetilde{\Omega}\lparen 1/\sqrt{\Delta}\rparen by Wang and Zhang (2023) and Weggemans (2024). Furthermore, our central result can be extended when the tested state is mixed: one-way LOCC is sufficient to realize the optimal tester.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 61 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 61"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Quantum pseudoentanglement",
        "Quantum algorithmic measurement",
        "Local tests of global entanglement and a counterexample to the generalized area law",
        "Distributed quantum inner product estimation",
        "Teleporting an unknown quantum state via dual classical and Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen channels",
        "Concentrating partial entanglement by local operations",
        "Simulating Hamiltonian dynamics with a truncated Taylor series",
        "Hamiltonian property testing",
        "Quantum amplitude amplification and estimation",
        "Quantum state certification",
        "Efficient algorithm for a quantum analogue of 2-SAT",
        "Communication via one- and two-particle operators on Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen states",
        "Exponential separations between learning with and without quantum memory",
        "Weak Fourier-Schur sampling, the hidden subgroup problem, and the quantum collision problem",
        "Entanglement spectrum in one-dimensional systems",
        "Everything you always wanted to know about LOCC (but were afraid to ask)",
        "Hamiltonian simulation using linear combinations of unitary operations",
        "Unitarity estimation for quantum channels",
        "Introduction to Representation Theory, volume 59 of Student Mathematical Library",
        "Can quantum-mechanical description of physical reality be considered complete?",
        "The approximation of one matrix by another of lower rank",
        "Quantum channel certification with incoherent measurements",
        "Representation Theory: A First Course, volume 129 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "Cryptographic distinguishability measures for quantum-mechanical states",
        "Quantum 3-SAT is 𝖰𝖬𝖠1subscript𝖰𝖬𝖠1\\mathsf{QMA}_{1}-complete",
        "A fast quantum mechanical algorithm for database search",
        "Quantum singular value transformation and beyond: exponential improvements for quantum matrix arithmetics",
        "The church of the symmetric subspace",
        "Detection theory and quantum mechanics",
        "Quantum entanglement",
        "Testing product states, quantum Merlin-Arthur games and tensor optimization",
        "A study of LOCC-detection of a maximally entangled state using hypothesis testing",
        "Probability inequalities for sums of bounded random variables",
        "Statistical decision theory for quantum systems",
        "(𝐺𝐿n,𝐺𝐿m)subscript𝐺𝐿𝑛subscript𝐺𝐿𝑚(\\mathit{GL}_{n},\\mathit{GL}_{m})-duality and symmetric plethysm",
        "Dimension independent disentanglers from unentanglement and applications",
        "An Introduction to Lie Groups and Lie Algebras, volume 113 of Cambridge Studies in Advanced Mathematics",
        "Topological entanglement entropy",
        "Entanglement spectrum as a generalization of entanglement entropy: identification of topological order in non-Abelian fractional quantum Hall effect states",
        "Detecting topological order in a ground state wave function",
        "Separation between entanglement criteria and entanglement detection protocols",
        "Test of purity by LOCC",
        "A survey of quantum property testing",
        "Universal distortion-free entanglement concentration",
        "Concurrence of mixed multipartite quantum states",
        "Quantum spectrum testing",
        "Matrix product state representations",
        "Optimal verification of entangled states with local measurements",
        "Entanglement spectrum of a topological phase in one dimension",
        "Linear Representations of Finite Groups, volume 42 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "Testing matrix product states",
        "Unitary property testing lower bounds by polynomials",
        "Possible generalization of Boltzmann-Gibbs statistics",
        "The Theory of Quantum Information",
        "Lower bounds for unitary property testing with proofs and advice",
        "Optimal verification of two-qubit pure states",
        "Quantum Information Theory",
        "Quantum lower bounds by sample-to-query lifting",
        "Time-efficient quantum entropy estimator via samplizer",
        "Entanglement entropy and entanglement spectrum of the Kitaev model",
        "Efficient verification of pure quantum states in the adversarial scenario"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 61 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Local Test for Unitarily Invariant Properties of Bipartite Quantum States, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
